abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Health and
            Demographic Project for Cote d'Ivoire was satisfactory.
            The project achieved most of its objectives, institutional
            development was partially achieved, sustainability is
            likely, and the performance of the Bank was satisfactory
            while the Borrower's was marginally satisfactory.
            Several lessons can be learned from this project. First,
            project scope and content should be coherent and support an
            agreed sector strategy and program that is based on a
            consensus and agreed upon by the different Government
            departments. Second, at the project's start, agreement
            should be reached on performance indicators. They should be
            reviewed through project launch workshops, annual
            programming exercises, and a mid-term assessment. Third,
            project management arrangements should be agreed upon,
            including staffing commitments and the roles of key
            technical units. Fourth, Bank missions should be more
            frequent, with a skill mix tailored to the technical and
            management requirements of the project. Finally, the Bank
            may want to consider a shorter timeframe for future
            projects, with phased implementation based on an agreed work
            program with the Government.
